awd_titl_txt: CHS:MEDIUM: Understanding Public Uses of Data and Dashboards
awd_abstract_narration:
Just as data-intensive technologies have spread in the business sector, so too have they increasingly been deployed by public institutions, including city, state, and local governments. Many public-serving institutions are currently expanding their capacity to create and use data by investing in infrastructure, hiring qualified experts such as data scientists or data engineers, and retooling their organizations to incorporate data gathering and data analysis into key processes. Central to these efforts are the production and circulation of "data dashboards". Dashboards are dynamic visual composites that summarize and collate data from multiple sources, and they serve as a primary site of the communication of data work to stakeholders and the public. Dashboards use graphical conventions to simplify and present the underlying data they represent, providing snapshots of civic activity derived from diverse data streams. By consulting data, publishing dashboards, and promoting this work to internal and external constituencies, public organizations hope to achieve more effective decision-making, competitive advantage over other organizations, more efficient allocation of resources, and greater understanding of the audiences they wish to reach. But public sector organizations differ from their private sector analogues in many vital ways and research to date has yet to fully explore exactly what public institutions mean when they aspire to make themselves data-driven, and the effects this has on public services and outcomes.

This project looks at public-serving data work in general and dashboards in particular as sites of interpretation and contestation, as artefacts that embody arguments about the public interest. The project team uses ethnographic approaches to study how people in public administration put data to work. In particular, the project team examines the role played by data dashboards, including how they are developed and how they are used to communicate with the public. This research focuses on four related questions: 1) How are dashboards and visualizations incorporated into organizational processes of deliberation, communication, and decision-making? 2) How do dashboards circulate within and amongst organizations with a public service mission? 3) How do domain experts interact with dashboards meant to inform their work? 4) How does the public interact with dashboards meant to explain organizational activity? This project will give insight into the construction of dashboards by focusing on the conditions and sites where they are produced, on the the data professionals and other who design, code, and implement them, on the platforms that make them possible, and on the audiences who encounter and interact with finished visualizations. This project uses two sites of important public work: city government and public education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
City governments, public schools, and other sites of public administration increasingly rely on large-scale data and tools to understand and manage their activities. One of the central tools that has been widely adopted is the "data dashboard" -- a collection of visual depictions of key parameters that describe the work being carried out in the organization. We are intereseted in how these dashboards are created and how they are put to work, both for managing work and for communicating inside and outside the organization.

We decided to look at this work "close up", working inside public organizations as far as possible, and working with the same data tools and training materials that they use in order to understand how the work of data-driven governance looks from their perspective. The answer, of course, is that it does not look just one way. Public organizations involve many different organizational units with different professional expertise, different kinds of problems, different relationships with the public, and different degrees of resources and support, all working in coordination (we hope). Accordingly, they vary in their enthusiasm for data technologies, in their expertise in putting data tools to use, and in their hopes for how data technoloies will move them forward. For example, some seek primarily to make their own work more visible in the organization while others, hope to find new channels for communicating with the public.

Most public organizations work with very tight budgets and under severe resource constraints. Taking on new ways of working, especailly with complicated digital tools, is frequently beyond their capacities. City planners, for instance, are experts on land use but not on data science. As a result, organizations like these rely a great deal on third party organizations and on volunteer labor to help them build the tools that they need. Creating public-private partnerships of this sort brings even more diversity of perspective into the efforts, since corporations unsurprisingly seek to make the organizations' needs fit the capacities of their tools rather than the other way around.

We have studied the processes that organizations engage in to create and employ data tools in their processes. Three primary lessons stand out.

First, data tools are novel technologies, but they do not appear out of thin air. They employ familiar tropes and patterns, particularly in their visual repesentations. Visual representations are communicative forms, and what they communicate lies not just in what they show but in how they show it. If we employ formal graphs, our data looks scientific and objective; if we employ "USA Today"-style infographics, our data looks friendly and approachable. The design of visual tools shapes the patterns of communication.

Second, developing digital processes requires creating alliances and affiliations both inside and outside the organization. Data is not static but flows, moving from place to place and from organzation to organization. It structures conversations and collaborations. Working with data provides a platform for new collaborations to emerge and for status relationships to be negotiated and reconstructed. The parterships and channels that data enables often matter more than the data itself.

Third, when one seeks to use data representations to make organizational processes visible, the challenges of "data literacy" quickly arises -- are other people able to "see" what the data people want to show? If it fails to communicate, is the problem in the data, in the visualization, or in the capacities of the audience to intepret what's going on? Frequently, people would conclude that it was the third, a problem of "literacy". However, sometimes publics, with a different perspective on what public organizatiions are delivering, simply see things differently -- they see the data through different lenses.

By focusing on organizational, institutional, and communicative dimensions of data and data tools, our research reminds us that data does not speak for itself. It suggests that the focus of attention needs to be not on what data might say but on how it is put to work in specific times and places, how it is used to achieve particular ends, and how it is made to support arguments and narratives that might lie far from its specific points of origin. We also demonstrate how we might partner with public organizations to engage in collaborative design and outreach around data tools. We are following these threads in ongoing research.
